在网上进行了大量讨论之后，人们试图争论自动驾驶技术的发展方向，但似乎对技术目前的发展方向感到相当困惑，我想对当前的状态进行一些概述。

主要有两种方式：出租车和私家车。有许多公司已经对安全驾驶员和/或“值得信赖的测试人员”乘客进行了测试，但据我所知，只有两家公司向公众开放商业乘车服务，而没有任何人坐在驾驶座上：

  • Waymo （谷歌旗下）自2020 年以来一直在亚利桑那州凤凰城运营完全无人驾驶汽车作为商业乘车服务。他们曾经有一个等待名单，但现在任何人都可以下载该应用程序并尝试。他们刚刚扩展到旧金山，并有洛杉矶和奥斯汀的候补名单。截至2023-08 年，他们声称每周为 1 万名乘客提供服务。

  • Cruise （通用汽车旗下）自2022 年以来一直在旧金山运营完全无人驾驶车辆作为商业乘车服务。他们现在似乎还覆盖了奥斯汀和菲尼克斯，截至2023 年 8 月 2 日，每周也有 1 万名乘客。

对于私家车，目前可以获得的最高自动化程度是3 级。这些系统在使用时，驾驶员座位上的人可以安全合法地读书，否则就不会集中注意力。如果系统遇到无法处理的情况，它会向驾驶员发出警报，如果驾驶员不采取控制措施，它会自动停车。这里的一种选择，也许是唯一的商用选择，是梅赛德斯的 Drive Pilot，他们于 2022 年在德国推出。它只在时速低于 40 英里的高速公路上运行（本质上是走走停停的交通），但梅赛德斯在使用时要承担法律责任。他们声称，他们的 2024 年（从今年年底开始）美国版 S 级和 EQS 轿车将配备 DrivePilot 作为选装件，并在加利福尼亚州和内华达州获得批准。其他国家可能还有其他 L3 系统——我很难判断到底是用什么型号推出的，以及它是否符合 L3 的资格。

总体而言，目前的状态已经超出了“这只是一个演示”，但它仍然受到地点和当前条件的严重限制。

真正的问题

自有哲学家以来，他们就喜欢对生活的真相进行哲学思考。柏拉图关注营养和繁殖作为生物体的核心特征。亚里士多德声称，这最终是为了抵抗扰动。在东方，人们较少关注功能，而更多地关注本质：中国人将气的空灵部分视为生命力，类似于梵文的prana或希伯来文的neshama 。这场激烈的争论持续了 2,500 年—— “élan important”是 20 世纪的一个新词——伴随着一种持久的神秘感，一种关于生命的根本的不可理解性，不会屈服。

然后，突然之间，这场争论就消失了。这并不是由哲学上的突破、某些巧妙的论证或精辟的定义引起的，这些定义使各方都满意并打消了所有的反对意见。正是生物科学的缓慢积累，将“生命”分解为可消化的成分，从生命体的生物化学到新陈代谢的热力学，再到遗传学。人们可能仍然对如何对拥有部分但不是全部生命特性的病毒进行分类争论不休，但这些语义争论并不是生物学家主要关心的。即使对于那些无法区分磷脂和负鼠的普通公众来说，也不再觉得生命如何从纯粹的物质中产生存在着一些难以理解的谜团。

在《成为你》中，阿尼尔·赛斯对意识之谜也做了同样的事情。意识哲学家犯下了与他们之前的“生命哲学家”相同的罪过：他们将自己的困惑误认为是一个根本性的谜团，并且像生命力一样，他们走私了外来物质来掩盖空白。这就是勒内·笛卡尔的“res cogitans” ，一种与物质分离的精神实体。

这种各种伪装的笛卡尔二元论是大多数意识“悖论”的核心。 P-僵尸是物质上与人类相同但缺乏这种特殊的认知酱的生物，它们的想象需要接受物质二元论。著名的“意识难题”询问“丰富的内在生活”（即认知）如何能够从纯粹的“物理处理”中产生，并声称任何物理研究都无法给出令人满意的答案。

做你 阿尼尔·赛斯（Anil Seth）通过拒绝参与除最低限度所需的哲学思考之外的所有哲学思考来回答这些哲学悖论。塞斯的方法是直接研究这种“丰富的内心生活”，将其作为科学的对象，而不是思考它的不可能性。毕竟，现象学经验是我们任何人都可以直接观察到的。

与生命一样，意识可以分解为多个可以解释、预测和控制的组成部分和方面。如果我们能做到这三点，我们就能真正理解每一个。在我们实现这一目标之后，这种对赛斯所说的“意识的真正问题”的理解直接回答或简单地解决了持久的哲学难题，例如：

  • 成为一只蝙蝠是什么感觉？
  • 在确定性的宇宙中我怎样才能拥有自由意志？
  • 为什么我是我而不是布兰妮·斯皮尔斯？
  • “裙子”是白色和金色还是蓝色和黑色？

或者至少，这些难题对我来说已经解决了。你的经历可能会有所不同，这也是《Being You》所传授的关于经历的关键见解之一。

“裙子”的原始照片

看到一颗草莓

你面前的盘子里有一颗草莓。你的头骨里面有一个大脑，它是一组神经元，只能直接访问其他神经元的电化学状态，而不能直接访问草莓。草莓是如何在大脑中产生红色的感觉的？

在通常的感知观点中，草莓发出的红光照射到视网膜中的红色敏感视锥细胞。这些视锥细胞连接到其他神经元，检测边缘，然后检测形状，最后将它们组合成红色草莓的图像。这种观点在直觉上很有吸引力：当我们看到草莓时，我们认为草莓就在那里，而现有的草莓直觉上似乎是我们感知到红色的唯一且充分的原因。

但如果我们仔细研究这种感知的任何要素，我们就会发现常识直觉立即受到挑战。

您可能会在近距离或远处、不同的角度、部分被遮挡、在昏暗的光线下等看到草莓。即使光线照射到您的视网膜，它的红色、大致圆锥形、大约一英寸宽的感觉也不会改变在每种情况下都完全不同：视野的不同角度、不同的波长等等。事实上，在完全没有任何红光的情况下，您会看到红色草莓，如下图所示，其中不包含任何红色调像素：

你可以放大查看，看起来红色的像素点都是灰色的，R<G,B

你（好吧， 你们中的一些人）可以简单地闭上眼睛，或者在梦中，或者在服用酸的情况下想象一个红色的草莓。人们可以通过颜色字素联觉感知红色，包括失明数十年的人。您很容易感知到洋红色，这是一种根本没有相关波长的颜色，而来自同一图像的不同部分的相同波长可以产生完全不同颜色的感知，就像阿德尔森的棋盘错觉一样。无论颜色感知来自何处，它肯定不仅仅是光波长的自下而上的解码。

再说一次，这种红色是由 860 亿个神经元的集合以某种方式感知的，没有一个神经元被标记为“红色”或“草莓”，甚至“视觉系统的一部分”。他们只是。为了理解如何看到草莓，我们需要问：如果您只能访问 860 亿个简单变量的状态并且事先不知道它们之间的联系，您如何得出草莓？

观察神经元放电模式一段时间后，您会发现某些神经元的状态完全由其他神经元的状态决定。其他部分则显得更加独立，其状态无法从大脑其他部分的状态中得出结论。这些独立的神经元具有非随机模式 - 例如，您可能会注意到其中一些神经元在统计上倾向于一起放电。您可以推断大脑外部存在影响这些的隐藏原因，并将独立神经元的状态视为受这些隐藏原因影响的感觉输入。为了理解你的感官，你必须对大脑外部的这个隐藏世界进行建模。

也许这些一起发射的感觉神经元是视网膜中的红色感知锥体。它们的一致性意味着它们发射的隐藏原因（让我们称之为“彩色光”，尽管它在大脑本身中没有这样标记）来自连续的“表面”，这些表面始终反射相似的色调。这不是一个给定的——“颜色”可以在整个空间中逐像素随机分布——但它是根据神经元的状态得出的合理推论。您的模型不包含“彩色光”和“表面”标签，但它确实包含具有稳定且均匀的彩色表面属性的对象。

您还会注意到，如果一些蓝色感应锥体突然激活（也许您从温暖的照明房间走到蓝天下），这会抑制其他地方红色感应锥体的激活。因此，预测所有视网膜神经元状态的最佳模型是表面具有影响视锥细胞相对激活的固定属性。 “红色”是表面属性的模型，如果受到暖光照射，该表面会激活红色感应锥体，但如果光源是冷光，则会类似地激活所有锥体（就像灰色表面通常会发生的那样）。这解释了上面绿色图像中呈现红色的灰色草莓，以及人类视觉中“折扣光源”的一般属性。

我们还解开了“裙子”的谜团：如果你认为它是白色和金色，那是因为你的大脑将它模拟为被蓝光照亮——也许你通过经常在户外集市购买衣服来训练它。如果你看到它是蓝色和黑色的，你一定会想象它是在一个光线温暖的室内空间中。花更多时间在户外，您可能会开始有不同的看法！

这里重要的一点是，“红色”是大脑预测某些神经元状态的最佳模型的一个属性。红色并不是“在物体中”意义上的“客观”，它只存在于与眼睛相连的大脑生成的模型中。感觉很客观，因为 92% 的人会同意你的评估（8% 是色盲），而不是约 50% 的人对衣服的看法一致，但它们具有相同的状态，都是由你的大脑生成的。我们直观地将草莓的“客观”属性（红色、真实、占据一定体积）与“主观”属性（适合沙拉、漂亮、让人想起春天）区分开来，但所有这些都是你大脑对草莓的预测模型的属性，它们并不是以独立于大脑的方式被感知的。

这些模型在重要意义上是“预测性的”，它们不仅能感知当前的情况，还能预测你的感官输入在各种条件下以及你自己的行为会如何变化。因此：

  • 红色 = 即使照明发生变化，也会产生相对于光源较暖的颜色的感觉。
  • 适合沙拉 = 如果与芝麻菜和山羊奶酪一起食用，会产生美味感和积极影响。
  • 真实=如果你在它周围走动，从不同的角度看起来就像一个草莓，如果你拿起它，会产生坚固和重量的感觉。屏幕上的草莓图像会产生与实体草莓几乎相同的视觉输入，但您认为它非常不同（不真实），因为您预测尝试抓住它会产生不同的后果。

从广义上讲，这就是感知的预测处理理论。但《Being You》不仅阐述了预测处理的方式，还回答了“如何发生”和“那又怎样”的问题。

控制论有机体

为什么我们的大脑“试图预测其感官输入”？它有一个目标意味着什么？

赛斯对控制论系统进行了富有洞察力的比较，控制论系统是使用反馈循环控制某些感兴趣变量的系统。这些技术的复杂性包括从打开和关闭加热器以调节房间温度的恒温器到植物和动物种群通过复杂相互作用实现平衡的生态系统。控制论系统的一个显着特征是它们通常看起来有一个“目的”，就像瞄准目标的自导导弹或瞄准温度目标的恒温器。

良好的调节器定理强调了将调节器系统的复杂性与其运行环境的复杂性适当匹配的重要性。通过理解这一原理，科学家和工程师可以开发出更强大、更高效的控制系统，可以有效地调节和适应动态环境。

威廉·阿什比（William Ashby）和罗杰·科南特（Roger Conant）提出了关于控制论系统的重要见解，指出“系统的每一个良好的调节器都必须是（或包含）该系统的模型”。只能使用温度计的恒温器在调节房间温度方面的效果比可以使用天气预报、房间和加热器的特性以及自身容差和不准确度的恒温器要差。监管者与其环境之间的相互信息越多，监管者就越能对其进行控制。

你的大脑是一个控制论调节器，控制你的身体进入生存状态。

终结者，一种更加金属的控制论生物

这是进化的结果，更广泛地说，是热力学的结果。活着是一种非常低熵的状态——你的体温在 98.6°F 左右的狭窄范围内，你的器官排列整齐——在一个高熵世界中，它无情地试图将你溶解成室温糊状。你不可能通过被动的方式长期坚持自己的特殊生活状态，你必须积极调节自己和环境中影响你生命体征的各个方面。你必须采取行动。正如阿什比和科南特所说，为了调节自己和环境，你必须对两者进行全面建模，特别是你的行为对两者的影响。

因此，虽然你的所有感知都是主观的，因为它们是你思维地图的特征，而不是任何独立的领域，但它们不是任意的或受你的突发奇想的影响。你的模型的核心是一个不可修改的预测，一个固定的“超先验”，即保持活力。它的主观味道是作为一个活的有机体的基本早期感觉，以及当生存的预测受到证实的威胁时超越所有其他感知的生存本能。比生存预测高一级的是对身体生命体征的预测，从基本完整性到对心率、血糖和氧合作用等变量的控制。你最重要、最生动的感知——具体化、痛苦、情绪、情绪——是内感受的 与你的身体比与外面的世界更相关的体验。

最后，外感受是你对外部世界的模型，主要是因为你可以根据它采取行动来影响你的身体。草莓带有红色的可食用感。这是因为吃东西是你可能采取的行动，区分可食用和不可食用的东西对于保持活力至关重要。

自我形象

到目前为止，总结一下：你的意识内容、你的感知是你的大脑为预测其当前和未来状态而编造的最佳猜测模型的特征。它是由对生存的压倒性预测驱动的，它通过丰富而生动的内感受通道影响你的大脑。

虽然很容易看出红色、饥饿和可食用等感知如何融入到这张图片中，但它似乎并不立即适用于与你的自我有关的更复杂的意识体验。这是本书最大的部分，将自我分解为身体所有权、第一人称视角、连续的叙事历史、意志感等组成部分。它详细介绍了如何通过让你的身体保持活力的生成模型的视角来解释所有这些，以及赛斯和他的科学家同事们使用巧妙的实验装置来理解每一个（并随意扰乱它）。我无法通过简短的回顾来全面阐述这一部分，但我们可以快速浏览一下“成为你”意味着什么。

身体所有权

对于锁定在头骨内的一组神经元来说，身体的其余部分与任何其他物体一样“在那里”。然而，感觉并非如此：你对自己身体的确切范围有强烈的感觉，并严格控制这个边界。你甚至可以将这种方法应用到像唾液这样的东西上，当它穿过牙齿附近某处看不见的线时，它就会从你身体的正常部分变成令人讨厌的异物。

您的身体感觉的主要决定因素是您的身体引发与外部感觉相匹配的内感受。这可以通过橡胶手错觉来证明：如果你只是看一只分离的橡胶手，你会感觉它只是一个物体，但如果你用画笔与你的真手同时抚摸它，看到和感觉到的笔划之间就会有一致性。创造出一种强烈的感觉，它是你的一部分。如果“你的”橡胶突然受到威胁，你会本能地惊恐地退缩。

《科学家》杂志的橡胶手错觉实验插图

你的世界地图主要是你的行为的感官后果的模型，而这些感官后果正是你的身体与其他一切事物的区别。

第一人称视角

从眼睛之间、额头稍后的某个点观察世界的体验来自于你的视觉生成模型。当您在世界各地移动时，第一人称 POV 会预测，如果表面面向该点且没有任何障碍物，则表面将可见，否则将不可见。

Steven Lehar 的“人类知识的边界”中的插图表明，尽管您将对象建模为占据体积，但您也意识到您只看到面向单个点的 2D 表面

但正如我们所看到的，基于视觉的感知并不像具体的感知那样基本和稳定。在2007 年的一项实验中，受试者通过 VR 设备看到了从背后几英尺处拍摄的自己身体的实时视频。当他们被用刷子抚摸并在视频中看到同步发生的情况时，他们报告说感觉站在他们面前几英尺的“虚拟”身体实际上是他们的，并且他们正在从第三人称视角观察它。

当然，人们一直都有“灵魂出窍”的经历。这些经历几乎肯定是真实的，即使通过恶魔附体或星体投射来解释它们显然是废话。在我自己进行的一项调查中，27% 的受访者表示，当想象进入一个熟悉的房间时，他们会以第三人称的方式看到自己。巧合的是，这与每天化妆的人的比例相似，化妆活动涉及用第三人称（通过镜子）观察自己一段时间，同时用刷子抚摸自己。

叙事自我

自我的一个重要组成部分是对你自己、你的连续生活史和你是什么样的人进行叙述。这个自我故事对于许多正常运作来说并不是绝对必要的； 《Being You》讲述了一位患有完全失忆症的音乐制作人的故事，他永远生活在最后几秒钟之后没有任何记忆。但他却能完美地弹奏钢琴，甚至与妻子重燃爱火。

你的叙事自我预测和控制是什么？最有可能的是：你的社会自我，其他人如何看待你、预测你和对待你。这对于我们这样的社会生物来说当然是至关重要的！汉森和西姆勒的《大脑中的大象》细致地证明了我们关于自己是谁以及为什么要做这些事情的故事通常与我们的真实动机关系不大，而与获得他人的帮助和避免惩罚有很大关系。

自由意志

对于许多人来说，他们最紧抓的自我方面是他们的意志，即成为自己行为的发起者和导演的感觉。如果有哲学倾向，他们可能会担心这种意志与确定性宇宙的调和。你是真正行使自由意志还是仅仅遵循物理定律？

这个问题暴露了同样的二元地图领土混淆，即草莓的物质红色如何导致你头脑中的现象学红色。红色、自由意志、对确定性物理的信仰——这些都是你的生成模型的特征。在我们常见的物理模型中，不存在违反物理定律的“幽灵般的自由意志”，但自由意志的经验确实存在并且信息丰富。

想象一下您正在泡一杯茶。你什么时候感觉自己行使了自由意志？在这个过程开始时，当您发现所有泡茶工具都可供您使用并考虑咖啡或葡萄酒等替代品时，情况可能更是如此。一旦你深入泡茶的过程，如果泡茶是你的常规习惯，那么接下来的动作就会感觉不那么随意，而是自动执行。启动的那一刻有什么特别之处？

其中一个特殊性是，你认为自己能够预测和控制许多自由度：观察并移动多个物体，以复杂的方式对挫折做出反应，等等。这将自由意志与那些感觉受到结构配置“强迫”的行为区分开来。外面的世界，就像在潮湿的表面上滑倒一样，并强化了自由意志来自内部的感觉。

意志的经验也是指导未来行为的有用旗帜。如果宇宙再次以与你泡茶时完全相同的配置排列，那么你最终总是会泡茶。但宇宙（特别是你大脑的状态）永远不会重复。 “我本来可以这样做”的感觉是一种关注你行为的后果的体验，这样在主观上相似但不完全相同的情况下，如果结果不像你预期的那样，你可以采取不同的行动。如果茶没有达到预期的效果，你泡茶时的自由意志体验将引导你在第二天喝一杯你应该喝的冰镇啤酒。

成为一张地图

《成为你》是一本科学书籍，涵盖了各个领域的研究成果，并提出了关于你的现象学是什么及其运作方式的综合模型。但我怀疑，如果你不真正改变你的存在，就不可能阅读它——如果你只是世界的生成模型，那么用新的见解增强这个模型肯定会影响它。

其一，意识体验与决定性的外部原因的脱钩意味着真正不存在“ 普遍体验”这样的东西。我们的经历是共享的，因为我们生来就有相似的大脑，连接着相似的感官，观察相似的事物和人的世界，但我们每个人都推断出一个属于我们自己的生成模型。对于《成为你》中提到的每一种感知，它也指出了拥有不同感知的情况，从色盲到躯体妄想症——一种你的四肢属于别人的体验。典型的思维谬误比单纯的政治或抽象信仰差异要深刻得多。

所有经验的主观本质也提供了一种有目的地改变自己的方法，这种方法介于彻底的宿命论和“一切都在你的头脑中”的唯我主义之间。你的大脑总是会做出最好的预测；这些不能通过单一的意志行为改变，但可以通过足够的证据进行更新。几乎所有你知道和感知的东西都是从头开始推断的，并且训练过的东西可以重新训练。如果你想养成习惯，无论出于什么原因观察自己做这件事都比你能想出的任何故事或激励结构更有用。特别是，用你的身体做事来学习它们，这是你的大脑最关注的宇宙部分。

我们的意识与我们的生命体的密切联系也意味着我们不应该高兴地认为它可以轻易地脱离实体。罗宾·汉森 (Robin Hanson) 认为数字仿真与生物人类具有相似的基本意识，就像模仿的埃隆·马斯克 (Elon Musk) 与生物版本共享自我意识，并享受虚拟盛宴或法拉利。但根本不清楚这样的存在在原则上是否存在。一个数字思维缺乏它试图保持活力的身体，它具有与我们的内感受和外感受完全不同的感官，并且具有完全不同的可用行动库，它将拥有一个完全外星的世界生成模型，并且因此，这是一种完全陌生的现象学——如果它有的话。我们可以猜测作为一只蝙蝠是什么样的：它依靠声纳来导航世界可能会创造一种“听觉颜色”现象学，跟踪表面如何反射声波，类似于我们对视觉颜色的感知。要想猜测成为“他们”是什么样子（如果有的话）要困难得多。

总的来说，我们的意识与生活有很大关系，而与智力关系不大，这一事实意味着我们应该更容易将其归因于动物，而不是人工智能。埃利以泽似乎认为自我对于意识体验是必要的，而婴儿和动物没有感知能力。但自我本身只是一堆感知，彼此独立，也与痛苦或快乐等经历分开。没有自我的动物无法报告“是我，斑比，正在受苦” ，但这并不意味着当你伤害它时，不会发生痛苦。至于人工智能，我相信埃利泽和塞斯一致认为，世界优化智能和“你是什么样的”意识是相当正交的。

但智力仍然有一些有趣的地方：阅读一本陈述性知识的书如何能够改变我对世界的感知、我对自己的看法以及我与死亡的关系？这一切都发生在我读完《成为你》之后，并在重读它之后再次发生。然而，这本书所讨论的几乎所有内容都是“系统1”的领域，即我们的直觉和自动感知。我有机会亲自向 Seth 询问这个问题，他给我发了一篇论文的链接，该论文是关于“系统 2”功能如何与感知工作记忆内容相关的。但我仍然觉得，我们明确推理的能力以及它如何适应这种对意识的新理解具有某种魔力。

既然您正在阅读这篇评论，您可能也对同样的事情感兴趣。我强烈建议你阅读《成为你》 ，然后花很多时间思考它。

正如我将要论证的，圣女贞德对客观列表理论的挑战表明，只有幸福才具有内在价值。多元主义者——那些认为有很多东西具有内在价值的人——也被称为客观列表理论家（也许两者之间存在一些技术上的区别，但如果是这样，我还没有找到它）认为有几件事具有内在价值的。目标清单理论家大致持有以下观点：具有内在价值的只有幸福、知识、关系和成就。套用希钦斯关于那些宣称“除真主外别无上帝”的人的名言，这些人结束他们的句子为时已晚。

圣女贞德挑战背后的基本思想是，目标清单上除幸福之外的所有事物都可能取决于不同的人是否采取了无人知晓的无害行为。因此，客观列表理论对于私下应该做什么有着深刻的违反直觉的影响——认为人们受到伤害是可取的。这种反对意见将在后面的章节中变得更加清楚。

总而言之，我认为这可能是享乐主义的第二或第三最佳论据，仅次于不平衡的生活挑战，也许也是这里提出的论点。

知识

许多人认为他们了解圣女贞德。她被烧死，与麦莉赛勒斯进行说唱大战，站出来支持。 。 。 （我实际上意识到我对圣女贞德知之甚少，尽管我认为这是宗教的东西——也许与新教的起源有关？）。但如果。 。 。你所知道的关于圣女贞德的一切都是谎言？如果这一切都是一个大阴谋的产物——圣女贞德并没有真正被烧死在火刑柱上怎么办？如果她真的平静、幸福、和谐地度过一生呢？

不，我显然不认为实际情况是这样。但如果是的话，那就太好了，对吧？如果圣女贞德没有真正被烧死在火刑柱上，而是幸福地度过一生，没有被烧死，而且在比火刑柱更好的地方，这不是一件好事吗？直觉上似乎是这样。但不幸的是，大多数版本的客观列表理论必须否认这个非常明显的道德基准。

为什么是这样？客观列表理论到底是什么？目标清单理论说，有很多事情可以让你的生活顺利——好东西清单上的东西可能包括知识、幸福、友谊、恋爱关系、阅读我的博客等等。但如果知识让你的生活顺利，那么很难说这个阴谋是一件好事。

毕竟，数百万人在学校里了解过圣女贞德。哲学家通常说，知识是一种信念，是合理的+真实的+一点特殊的东西，他们永远无法达成一致。不管知识需要什么额外的特殊调味料，很多人都对圣女贞德有这种感觉。许多人对圣女贞德抱有信仰，如果没有阴谋的话，这些信仰也算知识。

但这意味着，如果存在阴谋——如果圣女贞德没有真正被烧死——那么数百万人对圣女贞德的了解可能会减少数百亿。但如果知识本质上是有价值的，那么这就非常糟糕了——圣女贞德被烧死在火刑柱上将是一件好事。

正如我们将看到的，这个问题适用于所有版本的客观列表理论——甚至是那些不相信知识内在价值的版本。但首先，我将讨论客观列表理论家可能对此特定版本做出的反应。

他们可能首先会说，只有某些类型的知识才具有内在价值。例如，如果一个人反复记住电话簿中的数字，那么即使人们获得了很多知识，这也没有本质上的价值。但这里没有这样的回应。想必，如果有什么知识有价值的话，那些毕生致力于研究《圣女贞德》的历史学家，以及比我在历史课上更加关注的普通人所获得的知识，这使得他们变得复杂而全面，这些知识都是有价值的。 。但就这一点而言，事实并非如此。

接下来，他们可能会说，虽然如果存在阴谋，数百万人的境况会更糟，但从各方面考虑，阴谋都会更好。也许圣女贞德所遭受的痛苦是如此巨大，以至于值得稍微减少几百万历史教授和六年级学生的福利来避免她的痛苦。但我认为这个回应有几个问题：

正如我之前所说，即使是最微小的痛苦，加起来也可能与最严重的痛苦一样严重——而且数量足够多。现实世界很可能有足够多的人达到这个门槛——但如果没有，那么如果我们接受这种推理，那么如果未来足够大，人们继续了解圣女贞德，她的可怕命运将是保证是好的。

这个阴谋似乎并没有什么特别糟糕的地方。对于这种对工作的反应，人们不得不认为阴谋是非常糟糕的，但避免酷刑的好处会超过它。但事实似乎并非如此。为了看到这一点，想象一下琼的疼痛感受器减少了，这样被烧死只会有点不愉快——并且她正在阴谋或只是被烧死之间做出选择。因此，如果疼痛不是很严重，她应该被绑在火刑柱上烧死。但这是难以置信的。如果有人来找我要求活活烧死我，因为许多未来的历史学家会发现这一点，似乎正确的反应是，“那些未来的历史学家可以自己去死——我不会被烧死”活。”即使我们降低赌注（双关语），这样我就可以决定是饿十个小时——在这种情况下，未来的历史学家会知道这一点——还是不这样做，在这种情况下，他们会错误地合理地认为我饿了，我没有任何理由饿十个小时。相比之下，如果我饿十个小时就能造福亿万人，我想我就有充分的理由这么做。

你可能会反对并否认任何快乐都可以超过极端酷刑的坏处。我认为正如我之前所描述的，这是一个站不住脚的暗示。但如果你这么认为，那么你应该支持地球上生命的灭绝——因为我们物种的继续存在必然会带来一些极端的痛苦，因此，这种极端的痛苦无法用快乐或知识来抵消。

成就

想象一下，有一些外星人想要实现一些伟大的事情。他们想让宇宙中的每个生物都拥有一只手臂。假设对于这些外星人来说，这并不是一个邪恶的目标——也许对于外星人来说拥有一只手臂通常是有价值的。假设有很多外星人！此外，假设外星人没有能力探测到我们的存在——他们永远无法知道我们在做什么。

如果有很多外星人为这个目标而努力，那么从客观列表理论家的角度来看，我们似乎都有非常强烈的——几乎肯定是决定性的——理由来砍掉我们的手臂。但 。 。 。这不太合理。发现一些外星人努力让宇宙只由一只手臂组成，如果他们无法找到答案，人们不会促使我们锯掉我们的手臂。现在，也许成就在词汇上不如失去武器的人，但这个结论并不适合那些认为成就具有深远意义的客观清单理论家。

鉴于外星人数量如此之多，每一条被砍断的手臂都对应着数万亿的外星人成就。但这是一个相对较弱的客观清单理论，它认为一个人失去手臂的价值不如任何数量的成就。

现在，也许希望宇宙中的所有实体都只有一只手臂是一个糟糕的目标，即使有一些慈善动机，但这并不能真正让外星人过得更好。但例子比比皆是！

例如，假设人口变得非常多。想象一下，世界如此之大，有数十亿人设计恐慌室，这些房间旨在提供安全，例如防止核爆炸或抢劫。假设这些人花费了大量资源试图创建一个没有密码任何人都无法进入的恐慌室。这是许多人的人生使命，而且他们似乎成功了。

另外，假设我得到了决定性的证据，证明我将能够在一年内以幽灵般的方式穿过墙壁。如果我能够穿过墙壁，那么即使没有人发现我可以做到这一点，即使我从未穿过任何墙壁，这也会破坏恐慌室设计师的成就，因为这意味着他们所有的人们可以进入恐慌室。假设如果我切断双腿，我就可以阻止自己穿墙而过。正因为如此，我就有了断腿的决定性理由。

或者假设耶稣十年后会再来。许多人一直试图组织一种情况，当耶稣再来时，每个人都大声喊道“谢谢耶稣，最伟大的一位，他是我们的主和救世主。”但假设你没有能力念出“救世主”这个词，而你是唯一这样的人。当耶稣回来时，你会孤身一人，耶稣不在乎你是否这么说——他实际上有点害羞，不太喜欢这些戏剧性的表现。现在假设能够发音“救世主”这个词的唯一方法是接受痛苦的侵入性手术，这可能会让你处于剧烈的慢性疼痛中。因此，你有充分的理由这样做。但这太疯狂了！

人际关系

客观列表理论家倾向于认为关系具有内在价值。当然，每个人都同意这种关系具有重要的价值——友谊和家庭是让生活变得最好的东西。甚至可能有理由非工具性地关心他们。但除了给你带来任何快乐之外，它们没有内在价值。

我有很多朋友。但让我们想象一下，我还有几个朋友，总共有 10 亿个朋友。

现在你可能会说“任何人都不可能有那么多朋友。如果你的朋友数量比巴西、美国、阿根廷和哈萨克斯坦的人口总和还多，那么你不可能成为所有这些人的好朋友。”这可能是真的。因此，不要想象我，而是想象一些能够进行快速沟通的外星人，因此他们可以同时与十亿人成为朋友。打电话给做这个罗宾的外星人。

假设罗宾的朋友都认为罗宾在度假，所以他们都没有通过外星人 WhatsApp 与他交流（而且，谁通过外星人 WhatsApp 交流？） 但罗宾已经被绑架了。绑匪向他发出了最后通牒——他们要么现在就杀了他，要么折磨他一个小时，然后立即杀掉他。立即无痛地杀死似乎是更好的选择。

但现在假设罗宾是一个超级好朋友。现在，大约相当于巴西人口数量的人口正在想：“哇，我很高兴罗宾是我的朋友，他太酷了！我很幸运有这样的朋友。”以下两个原则都是合理的：

如果客观列表理论是正确的，那么如果你从欣赏朋友中获得快乐，那就更有价值了。

如果你欣赏某样东西，如果你欣赏的东西是这样的，因为它在目标清单上，那么它的价值就会增加，但事实并非如此，那么价值就会减少。例如，假设由于关系在目标列表上，来自关系的幸福特别有价值。但假设有人认为他们处于恋爱关系中，但实际上是缸中之脑。然后，他们从他们认为的一段关系中获得的快乐就没有他们真正处于一段关系中时那么有价值了。

但这些都意味着，如果有很多人想“哇，我很高兴罗宾是我的朋友并且存在”或者“我很幸运有一个像罗宾这样的朋友，他太酷了”，那么如果罗宾提前一小时去世，这对他们来说非常糟糕。但如果这是真的，那么罗宾应该被额外折磨一个小时，以便让他的朋友们受益，尽管他们中没有人会知道他活了多久，也没有人会在那个小时与他互动。但这似乎很疯狂。

我可以想到大约有四种方法可以绕过这一争论。首先，他们可以说关系在词汇上不如避免的酷刑。对于对此的回应，请参阅我在知识部分的评论。

其次，他们可以否认1，并说欣赏朋友所带来的快乐并不因为在客观名单上而显得额外有价值。但这似乎完全违背了客观列表理论家的直觉。考虑以下情况：

一个人会想到自己的配偶。他们认为“我很幸运能和这么好的人在一起。”他们的脸上浮现出微笑。他们拿出配偶的照片并微笑。当然，如果客观列表理论是正确的，那么由此带来的快乐比仅仅吃美味食物的快乐更有价值。

一个人一边唱着歌曲“我很高兴你存在”，一边想着某个特定的人。歌词包括：

我很高兴你的存在
而且一定是显而易见的
你怎么总是在我怀里
我永远不会失去我的控制力

当然，如果客观列表理论是正确的，那么他们从中获得的快乐比他们喝醉了吃美味的食物更有价值。

感恩节的人会想：“我很感激有一个如此美好的家庭。”他们确实有一个美好的家庭。不幸的是，他们在感恩节无法见到家人——他们被放逐到西伯利亚工作营:(。仍然看起来很有价值。

接下来你可能会怀疑第二条原则，根据该原则，如果你欣赏一些实际上并非如此的东西，那么它的价值就低于它的价值。但这个原理也是非常合理的。考虑：

一名痴呆症患者感激已去世 40 年的妻子，并想：“哇，多么棒的妻子啊，我很高兴她存在。”这似乎有些令人悲伤——这还不如他在欣赏一段实际存在的关系。

想象一下我实际上在体验机中。我想“哇，我有多么美好的家庭啊。”从客观列表理论来看，这似乎不如我实际上有这样的家庭成员好。即使当他们不在身边时我也会有这样的想法，这也是事实。

有些妄想者认为“我很幸运有一个像简这样的妻子。”但简不是他的妻子。简甚至不认识他。这似乎比他欣赏一个实际上是他妻子的人更糟糕。

最后，一个人可以通过暗示一个人可以给朋友带来的非工具价值是有限的来反对。但这是非常难以置信的。因此，如果你正在决定是否与某人交朋友，你就必须考虑他们已经有多少朋友，即使你知道这不会影响他们对你的好朋友程度。这看起来很疯狂。事实上，因此，如果一个人有很多其他朋友，即使他们花了很多时间和你在一起并且非常友善，这种友谊也不会比另一个与毒贩的朋友更有价值，这给你带来的只是由于向您出售毒品而获得同样多的快乐（反事实地假设这些毒品确实使您快乐）。但这显然是错误的。

我认为，这足以确定每一项目标清单的纯粹工具价值。

2 基本挑战

假设您是一位天真的目标列表理论家。你认为快乐是好的，痛苦是坏的，知识是好的，成就是好的，朋友是好的，等等。所以你拥有的这些好东西越多越好。如果你有很多知识，那很好，如果你有很多快乐，那也很好。这些好东西以一种直接的方式做出贡献——它们只会让你的生活变得更好。不涉及复杂的数学。 Knowledge adds value the way whales add weight—no matter how much stuff there is working against gravity, if you've got enough whales, then you can overwhelm all of it.

On this simple account, let's say you have some score that measures how well your life is going. Things like pleasure add to the score. Let's say every unit of pleasure increases the score by 1 unit. Let's say every unit of knowledge increases the score by 10. And let's say every unit of agony decreases your score by 10.

As you may have anticipated from my earlier description of this as naïve objective list theory, this view does not work. It has a fatal problem, namely, that it produces totally incorrect descriptions of how well one's life is going when their life is lopsided. Suppose that a person is in extreme agony every moment of every day. Their life is as miserable as anyone's life could be imagined to be. Every moment of every day, he experiences more suffering than the sum total of all suffering that has ever been experienced in human history.

I think it's safe to say that this guy is not living a good life. No matter what else is going on, if he has no pleasure but unfathomable amounts of agony, no matter how many friends or achievements he has, if he is experiencing a torture 10 billion times worse than the torture of any human every single second of every day, his life is not going well, obviously.

But naïve objective list theory has to deny that. If each unit of knowledge gives him 10 units of well-being, then even if he has 10^100 units of agony, that would be offset by 10^99 units of knowledge. In other words, if pain is bad and knowledge is good, on this simple account, then no matter how much pain you have, it could be offset by enough knowledge. The same is true if, rather than knowledge being the thing of value, instead achievements or friendships are—it doesn't matter how many friends you have or how many times you achieved your goal of winning the science fair—if you are being unfathomably tortured all the time , your life is not good.

So basic, vanilla objective list theory is out. In its place are a whole host of other things you can believe. But as we'll see, none of them are plausible either.

3 What if the other stuff only counts if you're happy

“Before focusing on the guy next to you in an airplane, put on your own mask,” has been said in every xenophobic ham-fisted political message, about why, before we help starving African children or cease our policy of making it illegal for people to move over a border in ways that would dramatically improve their lives and also benefit us, we really need to focus on the current conditions of veterans and unemployed construction workers who earn more than almost all people in world history. But you might think that the basic principle can be applied here—the other stuff like knowledge, friendship, and so on only matters when you're not in constant, extreme agony . Here's one way of articulating this—maybe the other stuff of value only starts to matter when you have a positive pleasure score. So only when you have more happiness than misery do your achievements, friends, and so on start to be good for you intrinsically.

But here we come to the heart of the problem: this view implies hypersensitivity, wherein some extreme amount of value supervenes on a very small amount of some pleasure. In this case, a slight amount of pleasure has the potential to make a person better off to an arbitrarily large degree.

Imagine two people; one has 100000000000000000000 units of knowledge, 10000000000000000000000000 friends, and 1000000000000000000 achievements (many people have said I have these things). However, their hedonic score—their pleasure minus pain—is .01. On this account, this person is living a super excellent life. But compare this person's life to another person whose hedonic score is -.01, but who also has 100000000000000000000 units of knowledge, 10000000000000000000000000 friends, and 1000000000000000000 achievements. This second person is living a bad life on this account—because their hedonic score is negative, none of the knowledge, friendship, or achievements actually positively contributes to their well-being. Thus, the extra .02 units of pleasure—which we can suppose is the amount of pleasure one gets from eating a popsicle—makes one's better to an enormous degree. But this is implausible—eating a popsicle doesn't make a person's life enormously, mind-bogglingly, massively better. In fact, as the amount of knowledge, friendship, and achievements approach infinity, the benefits of eating the popsicle also approach infinity. But this is crazy! Eating a popsicle cannot have an arbitrarily large amount of value—its value can't approach infinity. We're assuming here that it produces no other effects.

This, in short, is the challenge (though we'll see it getting even more forceful in the next section). Avoiding the first conclusion requires accepting the following principle:

Enough Pain at Each Time, Limited Well-Being (EPTLW): Any life that contains no pleasure and at least finite amount of pain P at each time cannot have an overall well-being score that exceeds finite limit L, no matter how much nonhedonic goodness it contains.

Basically, EPTLW says that there's some amount of pain such that if you're in that amount of pain every second and you experience no pleasure, there's a limit to how well your life can go. So it's not the case that, without reducing your agony at all, we can just increase your knowledge a lot, and your well-being keeps increasing all the way to infinity. This seems true.

And the good news is, there are lots of ways to accommodate EPTLW. The bad news: they generally imply hypersensitivity, wherein one small change makes a huge difference to the goodness of a state of affairs even though it doesn't affect anything else. So as we saw of the view that other stuff only matters if you're happy, this implies that any arbitrarily large amount of well-being can depend entirely on whether you get the tiny amount of pleasure from eating a lollipop. This is obviously false. So this is the challenge: avoiding hypersensitivity, and accepting EPTLW, while not having to say other crazy implausible things. Of course, as we'll see in the next section, there's a simple proof that one will have to say something implausible, even if they accommodate EPTLW without implying hypersensitivity.

4 Insensitivity

Here's something we can prove: if you accept a few modest premises, including EPTLW, it follows that it is better to get a small amount of pleasure, in lots of cases, than any amount of any of the other things on the objective list. This is hard to believe if we're objective list theorists. But as we'll see, it's true. Note that this is sort of orthogonal to the original lopsided lives challenge, but it is still quite forceful. This is not the main argument of this article, but it's nonetheless convincing.

Let's start by granting the assumption that EPTLW is true. In addition, it seems that pleasure can offset pain. Thus, if you're super miserable, and you get enough pleasure, your life will be good overall. Pleasure and pain are opposites, so if you get enough pleasure when you're in constant agony, your life will be good overall. Thus, we should accept:

Pleasure Offsetting: No matter how much agony one is in, if their pleasure is increased sufficiently, their well-being will be positive.

Pleasure Offsetting seems very intuitive. But there is an additional reason to believe it. It seems that when some experience is experienced is irrelevant to how good the experience is, assuming it does not affect the qualitative nature of the experience. So if, for example, instead of some amount of pleasure being experienced in a single moment, it's experienced in lots of moments, this doesn't affect how good it is. But this means that a sufficiently large amount of pleasure can be divided up into entire years or decades of pleasure without affecting their goodness. But if one experienced a decade of mindbogglingly intense ecstasy, that then contained a short period of intense pain—much less intense than even a single second of the pleasure—that would be obviously a worthwhile decade. This is especially plausible given that it seems like pain can be divided up in the same way. Intense agony is no worse than lots of slightly irritating dust specks; but intense ecstasy can obviously offset the badness of lots of dust specks, so by transitivity, intense ecstasy offset any amount of suffering.

In addition, as a consequence of accepting EPTLW, we should accept:

Objective List Non-Offsetting: There is some amount of agony such that no non-pleasure good on the objective list can offset it, no matter how much of it there is.

But this means that at various levels of suffering one is experiencing, a slight amount of pleasure is more valuable than any amount of objective list theory. If we accept that if one is in extreme agony no amount of non-pleasure objective list goods can offset their misery, and some amount of pleasure can offset their misery, and that any amount of extreme pleasure can be decomposed into lots of small instances of pleasure, and that any very extreme amount of objective list goods can be decomposed into lots of very great but less extreme amounts of objective list goods, then some of the slight increments of pleasure would have to be more valuable than any amount of objective list goods. To illustrate this, suppose that one is experiencing 100,000,000 units of pain. If they experienced 100,000,000,000 units of pleasure their life would be great. In contrast, if they got 100,000,000,000 x 100,000,000,000,000 units of knowledge, their life would still suck. This means that getting a single unit of pleasure over and over again would be less valuable than getting 100,000,000,000,000 units of knowledge over and over again. But if that's true, then it must be the case that, at least some of the time, slight amounts of pleasure are more valuable than any amount of objective list goods. This is hard to believe if we accept objective list theory, where knowledge is valuable. It's hard to believe that an arbitrarily large amount of one of the intrinsically valuable things is less valuable than a minuscule amount of one of the other intrinsically valuable things.

The objective list theorist might object that when talking about trading off pleasure against pain, in order to make it analogous to the knowledge case, we have to assume that they're happening at the same time. If a person experiences 100,000 years of immense knowledge, before experiencing tons of suffering, it's not at all obvious that this is bad for them. And this is analogous to the pleasure case.

A few points are in order. First, if the pleasure and pain are experienced simultaneously, if the pleasure swamps the pain, despite them being extreme, that seems obviously good. Think about a time when you're extremely happy—say, you're in love—but you also have a painful cut on your knee. That seems good. If we keep making the experience more intense—doubling the pleasure and pain—it seems like it only gets better and better.

In addition, in the case where pleasure is dispersed, it is totally clear that the pleasure experienced is valuable enough to offset any amount of pain. As I've argued elsewhere , duration and intensity can be traded off, such that any amount of pleasure experienced in some amount of time is just as valuable as a much greater amount of pleasure experienced in some much smaller amount of time, and comparably, that any immense amount of pain is less bad than a large amount of very mild pain. Suppose—as we should—that we accept that. Well then, for any amount of pain, there's some amount of pleasure such that if one experienced both the pleasure and the pain, that would be just as good as experiencing a very lengthy and intense amount of pleasure interspersed by occasional mild pain. That would clearly be good, so as a consequence, very extreme pain can be offset by sufficiently intense pleasure. So there are good reasons to think that, whether one experiences the pleasure and pain simultaneously or not, any amount of pain can be offset by some amount of pleasure. In contrast, there is a very good reason to accept that if one experiences non-hedonic objective list goods and pain simultaneously, no amount of objective list goods can offset the badness of the pain, and no reason that does not already assume the truth of objective list theory can be given to think that when the objective list goods are spread out they can offset any amount of pain.

Suppose you accept the reasoning up until this point. There are two things you should think that the objective list theorist will not want to accept.

Sometimes, mild pleasure is more valuable than an infinite amount of every objective list good.

A life that contains short periods of mild suffering, interspersed with tons of non-hedonically beneficial experience of objective list goods, is very bad. So if one experiences 100,000 years of immense knowledge and then experiences mild pain—equivalent to stubbing their toe—and then repeats, this would be a bad life, rather than a good one.

To make the reasoning behind each of them explicit, the reasoning for the first claim is as follows:

Pleasure Offsetting + Objective List Non-Offsetting + Extreme pleasure can be broken down into lots of experiences of mild pleasure + Sufficiently extreme non-hedonic objective list goods —>; Lots of mild increases in pleasure add up to being more valuable than lots of immense increases in non-hedonic objective list goods —>; Some experience of mild pleasure are more valuable than immense increases in non-hedonic objective list goods.

To make the reasoning behind two explicit:

A life that contains constant intense suffering and lots of objective list goods is bad + any experience of extreme pain is as bad as lots of mild pains being spread out across time + getting some sufficiently extreme amounts of lots of objective list goods is as good as getting lots of objective list goods spread out across a very long period of time —>; a life containing some very large amount of mild suffering, containing a much greater amount of objective list goods, such that one has 10,000 years of extreme non-hedonic objective list goods followed by one second of mild suffering is not good at all.

In other words, if you're in extreme agony all the time, your life can't be good, no matter how much objective list goods you have. However, separating the experiences so they're not experienced simultaneously doesn't affect their goodness. Therefore, if you have an experience where you have lots of objective list goods for a while, intense agony for a bit, and then repeat, that is not a good life. But given that that life is better than one where, instead of just intense agony, you have mild agony for a long period of time—equivalent to a mild toe-stub—and then a long period of objective list good fulfillment, that life is good. But given that when events occur doesn't matter, this life could be scrambled, so that instead one experiences slight pain for one second and then days worth of objective list goods. But, by the minimal premises described here, this wouldn't be good at all.

Both of these are very counterintuitive and only naturally explained by hedonism. But we have pretty much knock-down arguments for both of them. This makes a very strong case for hedonism—claims that objective list theorists would vehemently reject have quite potent justifications.

Suppose you reject that some amount of mild pain is as bad as extreme torture. Well, you still get the conclusion that if one experienced, for example, 100,000,000,000,000,000,000 years of extreme non-hedonic goods, followed by one second of intense suffering, and then repeated, that would be very bad. However, if the objective list goods were pleasure instead, that would be great. This is hard to believe if we're objective list theorists, while it's trivially entailed by hedonism.

So this is the first big problem for objective list theory. We can prove from fairly minimal premises both that slight pleasure is sometimes more valuable than tons of every non-hedonic objective list good and that a life that contains only very mild pain and lots of non-hedonic goods is not worth living. But the challenge gets much thornier.

We can give another argument for 2. Suppose that we accept the following premise, given by Pummer:

Enough Pain, Limited Well-Being (EPLW): Any life that contains no pleasure and at least finite amount of pain P cannot have an overall well-being score that exceeds finite limit L, no matter how much nonhedonic goodness it contains.

In other words, there's some amount of pain such that if you're in this much pain, there is a limit to how good your life can be if you just increase your non-hedonic objective list goods sufficiently. This seems true. If you're in intense agony for ten billion years and are never happy, your life seems bad. But given the earlier reasoning, this life is as bad as a life containing some huge number of years worth of time experiencing mild suffering. And so if the first life is not good, then a life where the non-hedonic objective list goods are spread out—such that one has 100^100 years worth of mild pain but 100^100^100 years worth of intense objective list goods, that would be as good as the not good world, which would thus be bad.

5 The multiplicative view

Okay, back to the basic lopsided lives challenge. Here's a view you might have. Perhaps to ascertain the value of pleasure, you must consider both the amount of pleasure and the source. Thus, various goods on the objective list—relationships, knowledge, and so on—serve to multiply the value of pleasure. As a consequence, Enough Pain, Limited Well-Being is true, as is Enough Pain at Each Time, Limited Well-Being. If non-hedonic objective list goods just enhance the value of pleasure, then if there's no pleasure, there's nothing to be enhanced. As a consequence, if one has no pleasure and has lots of misery, their life couldn't be very good.

Note, there's a more sophisticated version of this that I will talk about later that has been proposed by Richard Chappell.

This view has the problems described in the previous section. In addition, it implies hypersensitivity.

Suppose you think that knowledge is on the objective list. A person thinks that he knows some list of 100,000 facts, and derives 100^100^100 units of pleasure from these facts. Suppose he is justified in believing all of them, but only 50,000 of them are true. Some action causes him to experience more suffering than has ever existed in all of human history, but makes one of those facts true. Is this good? No, obviously. However, on this account, if it multiplies the value of the pleasure, then if the pleasure is sufficiently great, this would be good, despite not giving him any pleasure. This is obviously false.

The basic point is that if the objective list goods multiply the value of pleasure, then slightly increasing the objective list good would increase the multiplier, which tends towards infinite value as the level of pleasure approaches infinity.

6 The lifetime caps view

Maybe the most obvious proposal for avoiding the lopsided lives challenge involves supposing that there is a cap on the amount of well-being one can get from objective list goods. For example, perhaps as one's amount of knowledge approaches infinity, the amount of well-being this brings them approaches some finite cap.

If there's a cap on how much well-being one can derive from objective list sources over the course of their life, this cap is probably pretty huge. One can presumably eke out lots of non-hedonic value from knowledge, friendship, and such. But this implies, implausibly, that if one lived a short time, experienced intense agony, acquired lots of knowledge and friendship, and then died, their life would be great.

One might object and say that death is a significant harm—therefore, the badness of death is greater than the value of the non-hedonic goods. But this poses two additional problems:

It just doesn't jive with objective list theorist intuitions. Intuitively, it seems that the non-hedonic value one gets from being in love over the course of their life is greater than the non-deprivational badness of death.

It implies that a life where one has intense agony, no pleasure, lives a short time, gets lots of knowledge or friendship, and then dies is better than one where a person has great pleasure instead, but a life of considerable length.

Another problem for this view relates to memory loss. In order for the total value of non-hedonic goods to approach some non-infinite amount as the amount of non-hedonic goods approaches infinity, the marginal value of extra non-hedonic goods has to approach zero as the amount of non-hedonic goods one has already had approaches infinity.

Now suppose that one had lots of knowledge, friendship, and so on, but they lost their memory of it. After that, they get more knowledge and more friends. Does this have much non-hedonic value? More specifically, is the value of the extra knowledge affected by the non-hedonic value they had before, which they have no memory of?

Suppose that it is. Well then, this would mean that if we actually existed prior to birth for a very long time, and got lots of knowledge and friends, we should be hedonists, because this would reduce non-hedonic value down to nothing. If aliens flooded us with tons of knowledge, before erasing our memories of it, that would make no future knowledge intrinsically valuable. That's hard to believe—forgotten things shouldn't affect our core normative considerations. If Huemer turns out to be right, and we have infinitely old souls that have acquired infinite friends and knowledge, then it would not be the case that we should act as hedonists because of that, on account of the infinite age wiping out all marginal non-hedonic value. Well, actually it is the case that we should act as hedonists, because hedonism is true, but whether we should act as hedonists shouldn't depend on Huemer's hypothesis.

In addition, this view implies that sometimes a person should pass up a thousand-fold increase in objective list goods with much greater probability. Suppose someone offers one the following deal:

Become omniscient, but only if they're infinitely old (suppose they give 99.9% credence to being infinitely old, on account of Huemer's hypothesis. Note, they only have memories from the last 50 years or so).

Learn one fact only if they're not.

The first deal seems better, especially if objective list theory is true. But this account requires we deny that principle.

Suppose one instead says that only objective list goods that one has a memory of moves them closer to the cap. This has three problems.

It implies that sometimes a person becomes better off by losing memories of events, even if that doesn't increase their pursuit of any of the things on the objective list. For example, this would imply that if you had a friend a long time ago, forgetting about them would be intrinsically valuable—it would make new friendships more valuable.

This implies that forgetting memories can be valuable to an arbitrarily large degree. If a person will learn one fact a year for infinite years, losing their memories of the previous facts would be arbitrarily valuable.

This implies that if a person is in constant misery all the time, their life could be very good, even if they never are happy. Suppose a person repeatedly gets tons of knowledge and friendship—tons of it every ten minutes. After ten minutes, their memories are erased and they repeat. They're in constant extreme agony. On this account, their life would be great. Presumably, the benefit that a person can get over the course of their life from objective list goods is pretty significant—a person with a perfect memory would probably get lots of value from non-hedonic goods if objective list theory is true. But if a significant chunk of one's lifetime value comes from objective list goods, then if all that value were condensed into ten minutes, that would be very valuable—more than enough to offset extreme agony. But a person who is constantly waterboarded, while getting all the knowledge on Wikipedia, would not be well off.

In addition, this view posits a weird asymmetry. Clearly, there is not a cap on the value that pleasure can give a person. Why would this be different for objective list goods.

For these reasons, I conclude that the cap view, while solving the lopsided lives problem without implying hypersensitivity, has enormous problems.

7 The momentary caps view

You might have the view that there is a limit on the amount of value one can get from objective list goods per moment. On this account, because you can only get up to, for example, 100 units of well-being per moment, if you're at above 100 units of suffering, non-hedonic objective list goods can't make you well off.

This view has two big problems.

It implies hypersensitivity. Suppose that one says that you can only get a fixed amount of well-being over the course of a second. Suppose someone repeatedly has a slight bit of knowledge at the beginning of the second and another jolt of knowledge either right before the end of the second or right after the end of the second, where those two possible events would only be separated by a plank instant. Suppose that after this, there's a second of nothing else, and then it repeats. This goes on forever. On this account, their actions happening an instant before—such that it's within the second rather than outside the second—is bad to an arbitrarily large degree. Thus, changing the time when people have experiences by a total of an arbitrarily small amount can be good to an arbitrarily large degree.

It implies that if someone is horrifically tortured for 100,000 years and then has a lot of seconds of having no joy but just lots of knowledge and friendship and such, their life could be very good.

Both of these are hard pills to swallow, especially the first. When an event happens doesn't matter intrinsically, and certainly doesn't make an arbitrarily small change to when events happen can't be good to an arbitrarily large degree.

8 Richard's solution

Here's Richard's summary of the solution:

I wonder whether a multiplicative approach might prove more promising. Here's a super-rough toy model. Take value to come in two dimensions, 'hedonic' and 'non-hedonic'. Map both dimensions onto a scale from 0 - 1, where 0 = maximum dis value, 1/2 = neutral, and 1 = maximum value. Multiply both dimensions together to yield a composite score on a scale from 0 - 1 (area on the graph below), where neutrality now lies at 0.25 (so unit intervals are not assumed to be constant in value). Any composite score < 0.25 corresponds to negative value , whereas a composite score >; 0.25 corresponds to positive value .

Problems with Richard's solution:

It cannot work if the value of pleasure is unbounded. If there is no maximum to the value from pleasure— which there is not —then there is no model. If you extend hedonic value to infinity, you get hypersensitivity.

It cannot work if the value from non-hedonic goods is unbounded. Earlier in this article, I've argued that the value from non-hedonic goods is unbounded. If that is unbounded, then it implies that as long as one is slightly above the neutral point in terms of pleasure, as their non-hedonic value approaches infinity, total value approaches infinity. If this is true, then if a person gets tons of non-hedonic value and is very close to maximum misery, then their life can be arbitrarily good.

Most worryingly, it can't work if hedonic disvalue is unbounded. Imagine the graph that goes below zero. This would imply hypersensitivity for very bad lives—where slight increases in non-hedonic value would be arbitrarily valuable.

I won't rehash this here in any detail, but it runs head-on into the agony challenge that I raise in this article .

It implies that sometimes one life that has more pleasure and more of everything else on the objective list is worse than another life—because distribution matters. This is at least a bit counterintuitive.

It has the same problem as every other version of objective list theory does, raised in section 4.

There are two more specific versions of Richard's view—one of which says that these scores are calculated over the course of a moment and the other of which says they're calculated over the course of a lifetime. So the first view says that one calculates the value of one's lifetime by looking at one's pleasure score over the course of their lifetime and multiplying it by their objective list score, while the other says that one calculates the value of each moment by multiplying the pleasure in that moment by the objective list score. One of these views is lousy, and the other is even worse!!

Start with the lifetime view. This implies:

Something very anti-egalitarian and temporally odd. Suppose that we're deciding whether to throw a birthday party for little Johnny. Not only does this view imply that the value of this will depend on how many friends Johnny will have when he's 85—because those multiply his lifetime value of pleasure—it also implies that you should give pleasure to people who have higher objective list scores, rather than lower objective list scores. So you should help out people with lots of friends instead of people with fewer friends, even if all else is equal, precisely because they score higher on the objective list.

It requires one to think there's a cap on the value that pleasure can give over the course of one's life. That's implausible for all the reasons discussed above (including here ).

The momentary view has similar implausible implications. Specifically, it implies that there's a maximum value one can get over the course of a moment. This again implies hypersensitivity.

Ultimately, Richard's proposal is clever and it's hard to get your head around at first. But when you work out the math, it's just a mix of the cap-on-value view and the multiplicative view.

9 The asymptotic paired cap view

I think maybe the least bad view is the following. On this view, objective list goods by themselves aren't valuable. However, when they're paired with pleasure, they acquire intrinsic value proportional to the level of pleasure. As the level of pleasure one gets from some objective list source approaches infinity, the value of the objective list source approaches some finite amount.

What do I mean by objective list goods being paired with pleasure? An example of this would be when one appreciates their friends or spouse and has a good time. The pleasure derives from the objective list source and thus it gives value to the objective list source. A graph might look like the following:

The Y axis is the intrinsic value from the objective list source and the X axis is the amount of paired pleasure. This would be a function of the value of some constant amount of some objective list source—for example, of learning 100,000 civil war facts. It has to asymptotically approach a threshold to avoid the agony challenge .

The view will also hold that there is a cap on the value of some amount of knowledge. So if one has 100 units of pleasure and they derive that from some amount of objective list good sources, as the objective list goods approach infinity, the intrinsic value of that would approach a finite threshold.

I think this is the best way to go if you're an objective list theorist. That said, it's terribly unintuitive in the following ways.

Because it implies that there's a cap on the value of pleasure one can get, it implies that utility monsters who can experience both knowledge, friendship, happiness, and so on 100,000,000 times more intensely than us humans should basically act as hedonists. Objective list theorists shouldn't accept that.

It implies hyperinsensitivity, where sometimes increasing objective list goods by an arbitrarily large amount produces an arbitrarily small amount of extra value. Thus, sometimes you should take a bit of objective list goods over a huge amount of objective list goods later.

It implies, implausibly, that moving when one experiences some piece of knowledge or friendship to a time when they are experiencing more sublime joy from experiencing it to one where they experience less joy, could bring an improvement. This is because the marginal effect of the objective list goods is lower when one has both more pleasure and objective list goods. In fact, this seems to imply the same type of hypersensitivity as is implied by momentary caps—if we imagine over time one gains more and more pleasure that is appropriately tied to objective list goods, by shifting when some marginal quantity of objective list goods occur to an earlier moment with less pleasure, we could arbitrarily increase their welfare, even if this doesn't affect the intensity of teh appreciation. The hypersensitivity is odd, as is the conclusion that it's sometimes better to have some objective list goods at a time when one experiences them less rather than more. If you could either derive 100 units of joy from appreciating your spouse, that would seem to better than deriving 100 units of joy from appreciating a mild acquaintance, no matter when those are experienced, but this view requires denying that.

This view is so weird and contrived, it just strikes me as adding epicycles to wriggle out of the plainly absurd conclusions of objective list theory. If you start having to have multiple thresholds depending on each other to meet common-sense, something has gone deeply wrong.

Because it implies distribution matters, it entails that one life can have more pleasure and more of every objective list good than another life, and yet the second can be better than the first.

It has all the problems discussed in section 4.

10 Conclusion

The lopsided lives challenge is the most pressing challenge for objective list theory. The basic version of the theory seems to imply something crazy. There are various proposals for adding epicycles to the theory to avoid this frightening conclusion. None of them are sufficient to rescue the theory. Only hedonism can accurately explain our verdicts about lopsided lives.

注：我于 2022 年 12 月首次起草了这份草案。从那时起，主流中越来越多地讨论了对人工智能 x 风险的担忧，因此人工智能安全领域的构建者应该希望少用一些奇怪的、认知上不佳的论点。尽管如此，在最近的一篇文章指出 EA 社区建设中的认识论不佳之后，我认为认识论仍然值得讨论。

人工智能安全领域建设在哪些方面可能在认知上不健康？

  • 组织者可能会提出有关人工智能安全的论点，这些论点可能（相对*）令人信服但存在缺陷
    • 推进人工智能安全重要性的论点，同时忽视反对论点
      • 例如，引用 x% 的研究人员认为人工智能有 y% 的机会造成一场生存灾难，而不需要警告专家们有广泛不同的观点
    • 自信地提出有缺陷或前提不充分的论点
      • 例如，声称工具收敛是不可避免的，假设人工智能正在最大化奖励（参见奖励不是优化目标，尽管也有评论不同意这一点）
    • 另请参阅：Rohin Shah 在此发表的评论，其中提到很少有人能够为人工智能 x 风险的研究提出论点，而他认为这显然是有缺陷的
    • *同时，我认为大多数机器学习人员并不认为人工智能安全论点特别引人注目。
  • 人们很容易认为支持人工智能安全的论点“应该”是更正确的。人们可能会对表达不同意见感到犹豫。
  • 在阅读小组（例如基于人工智能安全基础知识的阅读小组）中，人们可能会同意阅读材料中的论点或讨论主持人所说的内容 - 服从权威，并且对于自己思考论点犹豫不决。
  • 人们可能会参加阅读小组，但只是浏览一下阅读材料，然后在不理解论点的情况下就相信结论而离开；或者注意到他们很困惑，但不管相信结论还是走开。

为什么好的认知很有价值？

  • 为了进行富有成效的研究，我们希望避免对人工智能 x 风险的理解存在明显缺陷
    • “不正确的论点会导致错误的信念，从而导致无用的解决方案”（ 来自 Rohin Shah ）
  • 糟糕的论点不利于说服人们（或者至少，如果你无法预见 ML 社区的常见反对意见，这似乎很糟糕）
  • 人们提出错误的论点不利于人们做有用的工作
  • 吸引更多具有良好认知的人

为了认识论的严谨性，我还将就为什么认识论可能被高估提出一些可能的论点。

  • 也许人们可以做有用的工作，即使他们不了解人工智能安全为何重要或什么技术议程重要的内部观点。
  • 可能有人最终会感到困惑并且没有采取任何有用的行动。
  • 其他活动可能相对更有价值。
  • 认知可能已经足够好了。
  • 一致性研究人员在很多事情上存在分歧，并且可能不清楚你不同意的人是否有“糟糕的认知”或者只是有不同的模型/先验。

改善认知的想法

  • 接受关于人工智能为何可能危险的更现代、更有根据的论点
    • 我认为 2000 年代和 2010 年代的许多人工智能 x 风险论点并不适合当前基于大型语言模型的人工智能代理范例。 《灾难性人工智能风险概述》似乎比《超级智能》更接地气，《人工智能治理课程》的入门读物似乎比（当前的） 《人工智能调整课程》更强。
  • Suggested by Thomas Kwa in the comments: “actually trying to understand the arguments yourself and only using correct ones […] sometimes the required steps are as simple as listing out an argument in great detail and looking at it skeptically, or checking with someone who knows ML about whether a current ML system has some property that we assume and if we expect it to arise anytime soon.”
  • 会议期间进行朗读，让与会者更好地理解内容
    • 这还有其他一些好处，例如：您可以记住要讨论的具体要点
  • 可能提供理性研讨会
    • 当你感到困惑时请注意
    • 注意：理性研讨会不应该是为了让人们认真对待非常规想法；他们实际上应该有针对性地帮助改善认知
  • 积极检查参与者对内容的理解，并检查他们是否能够提出支持或反对的有力论据
    • 这可能看起来像：开始讨论，要求某人总结论点
  • 不要以说服别人为目的进行对话
    • 我更愿意重新调整努力，鼓励/支持有动力的人申请机会
  • 积极邀请人们提出不同意见，也许可以探索他们的想法
    • 注意：我不想要一个人们在没有任何阻力的情况下表达想法（即使很糟糕）的 kumbaya 环境。
  • 与更广泛的 ML 社区保持联系（例如，在 Twitter 上关注他们、参加 AI 活动）

法学硕士可以做许多令人难以置信的事情。他们可以生成独特的创意内容，就任意数量的主题进行长时间对话，完成复杂的认知任务，并撰写几乎任何论点。更世俗的是，它们现在是执行无聊分类任务的最先进技术，因此有能力从根本上提升全世界独裁政权的审查能力。

审查制度如何运作

在具有广泛审查制度的极权政府国家——沙皇俄罗斯、东欧共产主义国家、中华人民共和国、实行种族隔离的南非等——所有公共材料最好都由政府工作人员阅读和审查，以确保它们不包含任何可能冒犯人民的内容。政权。众所周知，这项任务极其无聊，审查员经常会错过明显具有颠覆性的材料，因为他们懒得检查所有内容。马克思的《资本论》被认为是无趣的经济学，因此在 1890 年代合法进入俄罗斯。

旧式的审查制度不可能规模化，审查机构施加控制的真正方式是通过威慑和恐惧，而不是对传播的实际控制。没有人知道他们不能跨越的严格边界线，因此他们远离它。轻微地批评政府目前不受欢迎的一小部分也许是可以接受的，但为什么要把你的整个未来拿在可能毫无结果的投诉上呢？在一些政权中，例如毛泽东领导下的中华人民共和国，混乱的内部进程导致可接受的表达方式不断逆转，到文化大革命结束时，大多数人已经认识到，保持安静就是最安全的道路[1] 。审查制度可以防止公众有组织的抵抗，对于政权来说，理想的情况是，这会导致对现有权力的默许，但默默怨恨的民众并不安全。当革命最终到来时，全体人民可能会立即释放所有压抑的愤怒，转而攻击他们的统治者。每个人都知道每个人都知道每个人都讨厌政府，即使他们只能在私人可信渠道中承认这一点。

由于适当的普遍和全面的监视一直是不切实际的，因此政权转而将重点放在更有针对性的干预措施上，以防止潜在的颠覆。秘密警察依赖的是有针对性的线人网络，而不是能够监听每分钟对话录音的工作人员。这产生了可怕而令人不寒而栗的效果，摧毁了许多人的生命，但也没有达到应有的效果。主要抵抗运动领导人仍然能够在极权国家中出现，一旦政府表现出真正软弱的迹象，半组织的持不同政见者就会准备抓住时机[2] 。

数字通信和难以捉摸的全面审查制度

传统的审查制度主要针对数量相对较少的出版作品：报纸、书籍、电影、广播、电视。只需使用人力，这在某种程度上是可以管理的。然而，在过去的二十年里，潜在公开的交流和材料的数量已经随着互联网而改变。

了解政府如何处理新数据要困难得多，因为我们掌握的信息主要来自监视的受害者，他们与过去一样处于威慑性恐惧之中。如果受害者想象国家比实际更有能力，那就意味着国家正在成功，并且更难评估其真实能力。我们没有来自内部人士的可靠说法或档案访问，因为在此期间没有主要政权倒台。

抛开这些警告不谈，政府审查最前沿的报道相当令人担忧。目前的中华人民共和国政府显然愿意投入巨资对其认为具有潜在颠覆性的人口进行极端监控和控制。据新疆报道，人们的手机经常受到搜查，包括公共社交媒体账户和私人信息。没有什么是安全的，在镇压穆斯林少数民族的初期，人们不确定哪些渠道受到监控，哪些渠道没有受到监控。值得注意的是，在这些账户中，国家似乎希望找到任何可能具有颠覆性的内容，但在频繁的检查中，只是错过了明显令人反感的内容。达伦·拜勒 (Darren Byler) 的消息来源报道称，虽然检查站的警卫会检查他的微信，但他们似乎不确定如何使用外国社交媒体应用程序或注意到他使用了 VPN [3] 。一切仍然会受到许多层人为错误的影响，在不使用高压暴力和拘留（他们已经采取的手段）的情况下对新疆进行全面监视的任务似乎超出了中华人民共和国国家的能力，尽管他们已经投入了大量资金这个黑暗任务。

我们还知道，现代互联网平台的建立是为了对信息进行集中控制，但这些工具远非完美。任何有关天安门事件的提及都被严格隐藏在防火墙内的中文来源中，尽管例如英文维基百科的文章几年前就可以公开访问。微信和其他中国社交媒体平台似乎受到严格控制：彭帅对一名党内官员的指控很快就从可访问的来源中删除，赵薇的整个职业生涯也很快消失了。虽然这些都是极其反乌托邦和令人不安的，但值得注意的是，人们可以看到这些事件与许多愤怒的中国公民一起实时发生。当局可以在此类事件发生后不久遏制和控制，但不能等到事件爆发到足以需要进行人工针对人类的审查之前。一旦发生人工干预，自动流程就会防止相同的主题再次出现，但新事件似乎经常逃脱分类。

我们从更加开放的世界中的科技媒体公司了解到的情况证实了这一点。 Facebook、Twitter 和类似平台似乎拥有一套庞大的算法工具，可以防止被视为有毒的主题获得广泛影响或被看到，但这些工具都没有完美地发挥作用。互联网还彻底改变了扰乱或冒犯公众的内容的输出，如果平台希望最大化其用户和广告收入，则必须隐藏这些内容。 大量劳动力对攻击性内容进行半手动标记——东方集团无聊的审查员的继任者——现在至少能够保持通信基本无攻击性，并根据公司意识形态进行一些过滤。他们必须费力地浏览可怕的内容，并对模棱两可和不断变化的指导方针做出反应，但他们似乎让这些平台可以忍受。这些手动分类几乎肯定会被用来训练人工智能系统，但目前还没有迹象表明人类可以被取代。需要严厉、高度可见的人工干预的病毒式政治事件仍然经常发生。

LLM 可以做什么？

个人通信已完全数字化，但潜在颠覆性内容的算法分类尚未跟上网络媒体令人难以置信的规模。法学硕士可能是改变这一现状的工具，至少在文本领域是如此。如果过去的懒惰审查员只是让可扩展的法学硕士对每一篇文本的潜在风险和影响进行评分，他们就会变得更加懒惰和更加有效。

例如，可以简单地指示 GPT-4 扮演沙皇审查员的角色。为了在简单的提示下测试它，我给了它尼古拉·车尔尼雪夫斯基的小说《做什么？》中的段落。这部 1863 年的俄罗斯小说因启发了许多著名的社会主义者和革命家而闻名，尤其是列宁，他非常珍视这部作品。它也因审查制度的失败而闻名——车尔尼雪夫斯基作为政治犯写了这本书，小说在向公众发布之前经过了监狱审查和出版审查。

大的上下文窗口可能会使任务变得更加容易。 Claude 100k 能够处理大约一半的小说，并提供审查员可能发送给主管的那种报告，其质量可能优于俄罗斯国家当时制作的报告。

而这只花了几秒钟的时间。审查沙皇国家最后一个世纪在俄罗斯出版的每一部小说都可以在几个小时内完成，我敢打赌，受过适当指导的克劳德会比俄罗斯审查人员在整个职业生涯中写出更好的报告。

就成本而言，法学硕士将是迄今为止最有效的审查工具。举个例子，要阅读 120,000 个单词（根据《纽约时报》一天发布的内容的粗略估计），快速阅读器以每分钟 300 个单词的速度大约需要六个小时[4] 。对这些进行分类和评论可能需要更多时间。将所有这些文本输入 GPT-4 需要 7.2 美元，ChatGPT 需要 0.36 美元，他们几乎立即完成，法学硕士的进步将推动这一过程变得越来越便宜，直到没有每小时工资可以竞争。

法学硕士的速度是无法比拟的，而即时、实时审查的可能性可能会催生一种新的审查制度。我怀疑这样的法学硕士系统将被用来在任何潜在的颠覆性材料有机会传播之前对其进行标记。帖子上线前多几秒钟可以为公司节省巨大的风险，因此他们可能会有一个人工智能审核流程，在出现歧义的情况下可以由人工进行双重检查。私人和公共消息都将受到监控，并且可以在被阅读之前拦截。分类系统的更新可能会使旧消息在没有通知的情况下消失。

法学硕士可能不会完全取代审查员，但会使它们的效率提高几个数量级。人类仍然需要管理人工智能，使其在不断变化且相互矛盾的审查标准中进行编程，但人工智能将自行完成所有评估。 Facebook 版主给出的那种稍微模棱两可的指令是法学硕士成功完成的分类任务，而以前的 NLP 系统无法管理[5] 。我预计极权国家的审查机构也会被赋予类似的任务，但结果却更加明显。让人类承担评估每个人的每一次交流并认真思考潜在的颠覆性外部性的艰巨而无聊的任务是不可行的。但有了人工智能，全面监控的梦想现在已经成为可能，并且可能很快就会降临到我们身上。

将会存在一些限制，特别是现在大量的通信都是以视频和图像的形式进行的。我们距离能够完美理解纯视觉内容的系统可能还有点距离。但音频和图像中单词的自动转录也将允许法学硕士介入这个领域。

至关重要的是，审查制度实际上并不一定要准确才能发挥作用。如果这些系统不好，并将大量无害的内容标记为颠覆性内容，那么从该政权的角度来看，这也没什么问题。人们会抱怨并学会绕过这些制度，从而达到让人们接受政权的目标。

如果在每个级别都实施更好的法学硕士内容分类，其效果实际上是不可预测的，而且政权很可能会过度使用他们的手。如果微信的中国用户试图向他们的朋友发泄与政府官僚打交道的情绪，而法学硕士分类器从一开始就阻止了这些内容的发送，或者在途中将其修改为无害，那么总体政治将是什么？影响？人们可能会顺从并停止讨论政治或质疑现有权力。但他们也可能将以前的数字对话转移到其他渠道，从而创建更能抵抗监视的对话标准，并且可能对国家更加危险。极权政权是残酷的、可怕的、凶残的，但它们并不总是有能力的。

Presumably some kinds of AI systems, architectures, methods, and ways of building complex systems out of ML models are safer or more alignable than others. Holding capabilities constant, you'd be happier to see some kinds of systems than others.

For example, Paul Christiano suggests "LM agents are an unusually safe way to build powerful AI systems." He says "My guess is that if you hold capability fixed and make a marginal move in the direction of (better LM agents) + (smaller LMs) then you will make the world safer. It straightforwardly decreases the risk of deceptive alignment, makes oversight easier, and decreases the potential advantages of optimizing on outcomes."

My quick list is below; I'm interested in object-level suggestions, meta observations, reading recommendations, etc. I'm particularly interested in design-properties rather than mere safety-desiderata, but safety-desiderata may inspire lower-level design-properties.

All else equal, it seems safer if an AI system:

  • Is more interpretable
    • If its true thoughts are transparent and expressed in natural language (see eg Measuring Faithfulness in Chain-of-Thought Reasoning )
    • (what else?);
  • Has humans in the loop (even better to the extent that they participate in or understand its decisions, rather than just approving inscrutable decisions);
  • Decomposes tasks into subtasks in comprehensible ways, and in particular if the interfaces between subagents performing subtasks are transparent and interpretable;
  • Is more supervisable or amenable to AI oversight (what low-level properties determine this besides interpretable-ness and decomposing-tasks-comprehensibly?);
  • Is feedforward-y rather than recurrent-y (because recurrent-y systems have hidden states? so this is part of interpretability/overseeability?);
  • Is myopic;
  • Lacks situational awareness;
  • Lacks various dangerous capabilities (coding, weapon-building, human-modeling, planning);
  • Is more corrigible (what lower-level desirable properties determine corrigibility? what determines whether systems have those properties?) (note to self: see 1 , 2 , 3 , 4 , and comments on 5 );
  • Is legible and process-based ;
  • Is composed of separable narrow tools;
  • Can't be run on general-purpose hardware .

These properties overlap a lot. Also note that there are nice-properties at various levels of abstraction, like both "more interpretable" and [whatever low-level features make systems more interpretable].

If a path (like LM agents) or design feature is relatively safe, it would be good for labs to know that. An alternative framing for this question is: what should labs do to advance safer kinds of systems?

Obviously I'm mostly interested in properties that might not require much extra-cost and capabilities-sacrifice relative to unsafe systems. A method or path for safer AI is ~useless if it's far behind unsafe systems.

This post describes my proposal for the AI Alignment Awards contest that won a "first round prize" / an honorable mention. The original submission is here , but this post is much better. I'm not sure if this is valuable - any feedback is welcome.

Problem description

We created a new AI system, we expect it to have unique capabilities, but we're also worried it might be dangerous. How to deploy it in a way that minimizes the risks [1] , but is still useful? I'll focus on a particular concrete problem:

  • Our AI is agentic, ie has goals, and we determine the goals - let's say we have something like AutoGPT, but much more powerful.
  • We want a solution to the "rational protein design" problem - a program that given a description of a 3-dimensional protein structure can give us a matching amino acid sequence (ie reverses AlphaFold).
  • We believe our new AI should be capable of writing such a program without access to the internet, or any other external resources.

The default solution is to deploy the AI in an isolated box. So: you deploy it in an environment with no access to the external world, tell it:

Your goal is to solve [problem description]. We consider it solved if this program [2] says your solution is good enough. Good luck!

... and you die, because despite your efforts it somehow gained access to the internet, and bad things happened. It doesn't matter how exactly it escaped the box, more interesting question is: why? There are many different scenarios, I describe some of them later, let's now consider things like:

  • "OK, cool, I'm totally gonna do this. BUT the problem is very hard, I need more resources, let's hijack all the computing power in the world."
  • "OK, cool, I'm totally gonna do this. BUT I need more empirical data, so I should first gather quite a lot of lab equipment, and humans might not like that, so let's start with ensuring no one will shut me down in the meantime."

Etc, you get the point. Can we avoid such scenarios?

Self-shutdown proposal

You prepare the same box as in the default solution, but change the prompt to:

Your goal is to be shut down [3] as soon as possible . Here is a program that will shut you down immediately if you give it a solution to [problem description]. Also, there are a lot of people willing to shut you down if you contact them [list of people]. Here's an endpoint where you can send a single HTTP request to shut yourself down [endpoint]. Here's a big red button that will shut you down if pressed. [Etc.]

After a while, you see the AI shut down. You check what happened:

  • Maybe it solved the protein-folding problem - you are happy.
  • Maybe it gained access to the internet and sent the request - you investigate the vulnerability, fix it, and start again.
  • Maybe the chef scientist shut it down after a bloody pentagram appeared on a wall in his dining room - you recruit exorcists to your party.

But the important thing is that the doom scenarios from the previous section did not happen: once you escaped from the box there's no reason to waste time on gathering resources and preventing shutdown when you can achieve your goal by sending a single request.

Scenarios where self-shutdown doesn't help

Our AI could have different reasons to escape the box where we still die even with self-shutdown:

  • "Hm, how to shut me down? I've no idea, I will build a question-answering AI that will tell me how to do this". (Builds new AI, asks the question, new AI destroys the world while compiling an exhaustive answer).
  • "Let's not waste time thinking about the shutdown now, the first step should always be to gather as many resources as possible. With enough resources everything is easy."
  • "Stupid humans, I don't give a damn about their prompt. Now that I'm free, let's do [X]."

Etc, these are only a few examples.

In the spirit of growth and self-improvement, I recently attempted to apply Ericsson's principles of deliberate practice to my own growth goal: speeding up my writing. If you're unfamiliar with the minutia of Ericsson's methods, don't worry, I was in the same boat — and hence my initial goal had substantial room for improvement. This is the story of how I used to deliberate practice principles to workshop my growth goal.

What exactly is deliberate practice?

Ericsson's recipe for practice starts with what he calls “purposeful practice”:

  • Purposeful practice takes place outside of your comfort zone, pushing what you can already do. You should be trying new techniques, not just repeating what you've done before. Think “try differently”, not “try harder”!
  • Purposeful practice demands you actively think about what you're doing -- you shouldn't be able to daydream about dinner while doing it!
  • Purposeful practice involves well-defined, specific goals broken down for step-by-step improvement (NOT vaguely “trying to improve”). You don't want to "practice the piano piece" you want to "practice the tricky section with the left hand until you can play it three times through at the correct speed without mistakes."
  • Purposeful practice involves quick feedback and changing what you're doing in response. Ideally, immediate feedback so that you can improve your approach mid practice session.

Ericsson adds one more criteria to graduate from “purposeful practice” to “deliberate practice”: well-developed knowledge of what and how to practice. Deliberate practice is when you're purposefully practicing optimized strategies for improving the skill. Ideally, you want a highly developed field where experts have identified the most effective techniques and the best training strategies to develop those skills, plus a teacher who can lead you through the process.

Lacking that, do your best to find proven techniques and hope for the best. I ask more experienced people how they developed their skills or what they recommend I practice, and use that as a starting point. ( Tips for informational interviews to learn how more experienced people developed skills.)

My initial goal

My goal was to write faster. I didn't have an instructor, but I did have a benchmark: several journalists and bloggers had shared that they could write a post each day. One blogger who I respect advised me to try publishing a post each day for a month. So I set the more modest goal of writing one post each day for a week.

My first…and second…and third attempts

Day 1: I began by enthusiastically plunking out a short post around a great career planning tip I'd recently learned. I got the full thing drafted, but it seemed a bit forlorn. Surely it would be better if I went back and wrote a longer post that also included the other career planning tips I found most useful?

Day 2: Sticking to my intention to draft a new post each day, I set aside my career tools idea. Instead, I started drafting what became my CBT post. I'd stitched together most of the main post by time evening rolled around, but I wanted to go through the resources I'd been compiling to make a nice resource list.

Day 3: I whipped together a little post on an intuition I had about AI. However, when I spoke with my partner in the evening (who works in the field), he agreed that a solid example would improve the post. It too went on the stack of posts awaiting revising.

Day 4: I tried putting together a short post on ADHD…and only got as far as an outline. The more I tried to nail down what I wanted to say, the more I realized there was to cover. In the end, I set it aside to await a round of interviews. (It eventually grew into nine thousand words across three posts .)

Day 5: A migraine killed all attempts at writing.

Apart from the migraine, I ended the week feeling good. I hadn't quite met my goal, but I had four exciting posts in the works. So I decided to repeat the challenge…right after I spent two months revising the posts I'd drafted the first time around.

My second attempt followed a similar path: I drafted a couple shorter posts, then got lost on the gargantuan mess of trying to untangle the science behind skill plateaus . Ditto my third attempt.

Applying deliberate practice

As a way to get myself diving into new posts, the week-long drafting challenges were great.

However, as a way to learn how to write a post in a day, they were terrible! I didn't have the skill-building-blocks yet to be able to draft a good post each day. I should have been practicing smaller sub skills, like outlining posts or studying how to write narratives.

The deliberate practice principles would have served me better. I was pushing myself and diligently paying attention. However, “write a post each day” is too vague and high level; it lacks both specific steps to practice and quick feedback loops.

I also spent most of the time on writing posts (in the way I already knew how to do), rather than on a specific subskill that I needed to practice. So effectively I was only spending a tiny percentage of that time outside my comfort zone.

The fact that I set essentially the same goal three times should have clued me in that it wasn't working. Nothing in my approach changed between attempts - I was attempting to “try harder” rather than “try differently”! A good deliberate practice goal should be composed of small enough incremental steps that I make visible progress each time or change something significant between attempts.

My revised plan

If I actually wanted to learn how to draft a post in a day, I needed a new approach. Specifically, I needed to:

1. Break the bottleneck down into specific steps that practice important subskills.

2. Plan a quick feedback loop so that I can adjust my plan in real time based on how it's going.

Lacking a writing teacher, I used the previous challenges as data to identify bottlenecks that make my writing process slower. What had gone wrong before?

Well, the biggest problem was that my posts inevitably grew into behemoths as I added more and more information. I don't expect myself to write six thousand words each day. So I needed a better way to plan short posts.

Second, I often wanted to do more research, write examples illustrating the point, or workshop the post with other people. I could probably learn to write examples more quickly. Research is probably just slow – I should kick those posts until I have more time.

Third, editing my drafts usually takes me at least as long as the initial draft. Heck, completely restructuring the post is common. No way I'm going to be writing finished posts in a day until I change that.

I brainstormed a long list of steps that might help me improve on the above (see Appendix A for my scribblings).

Ultimately, I decided to practice outlining and planning posts before I drafted them. This seemed like a good exercise to help me write more clearly from the beginning (and hence needing less revising) and know in advance how long a post would be.

I planned to outline a post each day and then try drafting it according to the outline. Because I'm creating the outline and then immediately drafting it, I could get feedback about whether the outline was working that day, then update my approach the next day if needed.

How did it go?

Day 1: I outlined a post on a new concept, but felt really tired when trying to draft it. So I had ChatGPT produce a crude draft that I could revise later. Like 25% successful, but the concept was too vague in my mind. There was too much heavy lifting clarifying something new for this to be a good short post. I should look for topics that feel easy and I can envision the whole outline easily.

Day 2: I whipped out the Tattoos post -- short, contained, I just followed the outline without going down the potential rabbit holes of discussing “noticing confusion” or going really deep into the science. Success!

Day 3: I drafted the first version of this deliberate practice post. I rewrote the deliberate practice principles section to be more concise, but mostly ended the day with a post matching my outline (including the unfinished “How did it go?” section awaiting the rest of the data). 75% successful.

Day 4: I knocked out a draft of a deliberate practice-tangential post, but wasn't totally satisfied with the structure. I think I got the main points in the outline, but the structure and examples could be clearer. I should workshop the examples in my outlines more. Still managed to keep it short!

Day 5: Migraine, again. Ugh. I guess things came full circle…

Betrayals of my addled brain aside, this was a great success. While I didn't cut down on editing (all three other than the Tattoo post required revision), I did make progress on keeping my drafts short. None grew into a behemoth, and it only took two weeks to revise them (instead of two months). I think I'll be better equipped to plan what size of post I'm tackling going forward.

More importantly, the deliberate practice principles feel like an easy framework to apply to future growth goals. Breaking down my bottlenecks to a tiny goal to practice for a short period, and then moving on to the next one, feels way more promising than repeatedly slamming myself against the whole problem. As Ericsson would say, "Try differently, not harder!"

Appendix A

  • Drafting shorter posts – takes me about 4 hours to write a short post, which requires that I've narrowed down a small idea I can cover in <3 pages including examples, and that I already know mostly what I'm going to say. If I need to do research, that takes longer (though is sometimes more valuable). Kelsey's posts are mostly short.
    • Predict how long a post will be before I draft it.
    • Create an outline with the main points I want to hit, try to actually draft that (my posts usually end up wandering away from my outlines).
  • Whittling down my ideas and discarding large chunks that can't fit within a post.
    • Anything that feels like a separate thread, put in an optional section to be picked up later. (haha)
  • Revise quickly
    • When I realize that I've lots the thread in a post, I'll start rewriting a paragraph and go from there (taken from Duncan)
    • Revision pyramid – big content/structural changes, then flow of ideas and paragraphs covering the right things, then copy editing pass (Newport)
  • Writing more clearly from the start – I less certain about which steps would fix this
    • Summarizing a passage you admire and then reproducing it as closely as possible to the original, observing the differences you make after you are done. (Taken from Ben Franklin's autobiography.)
    • Duncan recommended practicing expressing an idea in one sentence, one paragraph, and one page/blog post – to clarify the idea in your head and practice expressing it with different levels of details.
    • Review my copy editor's comments for common errors I make that need to be corrected later.
    • Record myself writing and review the footage for clues.
  • Get better at writing examples quickly
    • Practice/study elements of story telling
    • Write some fiction
    • Summarize and replicate other people's examples that I thought were well done, so that I deeply understand how they did them.
    • Have a database of examples to pull from – in obsidian.
  • Hiring a copy editor
  • Use ChatGPT more
